snippet: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.
abstract: Sunni militants, many aligned with radical Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, are consolidating and expanding their takeover of northern Iraq, seizing Tikrit, threatening oil-refining town of Baiji and pushing south toward Baghdad; militant groups, including Baathist commanders from Hussein era, appear to have banded together with goal of ousting government of Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

byline.original: By SUADAD AL-SALHY and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Suadad al-Salhy reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Istanbul. Reporting was contributed by Alan Cowell from London, Rick Gladstone from New York, Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul, and Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran.

lead_paragraph: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.

headline.sub: Tikrit Falls; Reports of Battle in Samarra, 70 Miles From the Capital
headline.main: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
headline.print_headline: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital

keywords.value: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
keywords.name: organizations
